message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which is a severe and life-threatening skin reaction associated with some medications. The annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles are characteristic symptoms of this syndrome. There is no significant lymphadenopathy, which distinguishes it from pemphigus vulgaris. Bullous pemphigoid typically presents with tense blisters, while Drug-induced lupus erythematosus is associated with joint pain, fever, and rashes on the face or other areas exposed to UV light.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome. The new medication is likely the cause, and the characteristic skin and mucosal findings are indicative of this condition. Bullous pemphigoid presents with tense blisters, Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid blisters, and drug-induced lupus erythematosus presents with systemic symptoms such as arthralgias and serositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple symptoms and skin findings that suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome. The recent onset of a new medicine also supports this diagnosis. Bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris are autoimmune skin disorders with different clinical features, and drug-induced lupus erythematosus typically presents with systemic symptoms such as joint pain and fever.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings of conjunctival injection, oral and genital ulceration, skin rash with desquamation and epidermis separation suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which is often drug-induced. Bullous pemphigoid and Pemphigus vulgaris typically present with blistering, while drug-induced lupus erythematosus presents with joint pain and fever.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome, characterized by a painful rash involving the mucous membranes and skin, fever, and malaise. The new medicine she started for trigeminal neuralgia is a potential trigger for Stevens-Johnson syndrome. None of the other options match with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which is commonly caused by medications. The rash, ulcers in the mouth, and conjunctival injection are all pointing to this diagnosis. The other options do not fit the patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome. The painful, itchy rash and conjunctival injection are indicative of this syndrome. The recent medication change may have triggered this reaction. The other options do not present with the same symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which includes fever, malaise, skin rash, and conjunctivitis. The new medicine could have triggered this condition, as some drugs are known to cause Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris usually do not cause fever or conjunctivitis. Drug-induced lupus erythematosus can cause skin rash but typically not the symptoms described, such as conjunctivitis and ulceration on the tongue and palate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which can be caused by a drug reaction. The symptoms include a painful rash on the chest, face, limbs, palms, and soles, as well as fever, blistering, and ulceration of the skin and mucous membranes. The other options do not fit the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the painful rash that started on the chest and face and spread to the limbs, palms, and soles, suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome. The conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate, along with the skin findings, are also characteristic of this syndrome. The recent initiation of a new medication further supports the diagnosis. Bullous pemphigoid, pemphigus vulgaris, and drug-induced lupus erythematosus are less likely given the symptoms and physical findings described.
